title: 113_hr4467
content: The Act may be cited as the "Best Return on America's Investment Now Act" or the "BRAIN Act." It includes provisions for immigrant visas for certain advanced STEM graduates. The "Best Return on America's Investment Now Act" or the "BRAIN Act" includes provisions for immigrant visas for advanced STEM graduates holding doctorate degrees from U.S. institutions in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Visas will be allocated to qualified immigrants meeting specific criteria. The "BRAIN Act" allows immigrant visas for STEM graduates with U.S. doctorates in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The Act defines terms like distance education and specifies eligible fields of study. The "BRAIN Act" allows immigrant visas for STEM graduates with U.S. doctorates in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics from designated institutions. The "BRAIN Act" allows immigrant visas for STEM graduates with U.S. doctorates in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics from designated institutions recognized for research activity equivalent to doctorate-granting universities classified by the Carnegie Foundation. Amendments are made to the procedure for granting immigrant status under the Act. The "BRAIN Act" introduces processing standards for petitions related to alien beneficiaries qualifying under section 203(b)(6), requiring adjudication within specific timeframes and notification of approval status within 30 days of filing. The petition must meet approval standards, with reasons provided if it does not. Amendments are made to sections regarding skilled workers and a study on the National Science Foundation's classification authority. Effective date for these changes is October 1, 2014. The Secretary of Homeland Security can accept petitions before October 1, 2014 under certain sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 3. Numerical limitation to any single foreign state. Amendments are made to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding employment-based immigrants and countries at ceiling. The changes involve subsections and paragraphs within the Act. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act involve changes to subsections and paragraphs, with an effective date of October 1, 2014, applying to fiscal years starting on or after that date. SEC. 4. PERMANENT PRIORITY DATES. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish permanent priority dates for employment-based petitions. The priority date will be the date of filing with the Secretary of Homeland Security, unless preceded by a labor certification filing with the Secretary of Labor. Beneficiaries of approvable petitions will retain their priority date for subsequent petitions. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish permanent priority dates for employment-based petitions, effective October 1, 2014. The amendment applies to aliens with a classification petition pending on or after that date.
